name: Bengal Famine of 1943
description: A catastrophic famine in British-ruled Bengal caused by wartime policies, including rice exports and denial of food imports. Winston Churchill's War Cabinet prioritized military needs over famine relief. Three million Bengalis died while food stocks existed elsewhere in the empire.

mortality.note: Deaths from starvation and disease during WWII. Rice exports continued. Churchill rejected relief ships. His quote: 'Indians breeding like rabbits.' Separate from British India Famines (1876-1902).

rationales.systematic_intensity: British war policies: rice denial, boat denial, inflation. Churchill's priorities.
rationales.profit: War economy prioritized over Bengali lives. Resources directed to military.
rationales.ideology: Racial attitudes toward Indians, but primarily wartime indifference not targeting.
rationales.complicity: British government, military, and hoarders contributed. Debate continues on intentionality.

analysis.pattern_note: Churchill's famine. Rice diverted for war effort and exports while millions starved. Relief ships denied. 'Denial policy' destroyed boats and rice stocks to prevent Japanese use. Churchill blamed Indians for 'breeding like rabbits.' Distinct from 1876-1902 famines - this was WWII-era with Churchill directly responsible. Still politically sensitive in UK.
analysis.root_causes: WWII resource diversion, colonial racism, policy failures, Japanese threat

sources.title: Churchill's Secret War: The British Empire and the Ravaging of India During World War II
